content: The Armed Forces Tax Fairness Act of 2003, also known as the "Armed Forces Tax Fairness Act," includes provisions related to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It introduces a special rule for members of the uniformed services and foreign service regarding the exclusion of gain from the sale of a principal residence. The Armed Forces Tax Fairness Act of 2003 introduces a special rule for members of the uniformed services and foreign service regarding the exclusion of gain from the sale of a principal residence. This rule allows the suspension of the 5-year period for selling a property during qualified official extended duty, with a maximum extension of 5 years. The special rule under the Armed Forces Tax Fairness Act of 2003 allows for the suspension of the 5-year period for selling a property during qualified official extended duty, with a maximum extension of 5 years. The term 'member of the Foreign Service' is defined as a member of the Service under the Foreign Service Act of 1980. 'Extended duty' refers to active duty exceeding 180 days or for an indefinite period. An election under special rules allows for the suspension of the 5-year period for selling a property during extended duty. The amendment allows for the revocation of an election at any time. The effective date is retroactive to the Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997. Refund limitations may be waived within a year of enactment. Refunds or credits can be allowed even after the period specified by law if a claim is filed before the deadline. SEC. 3. RESTORATION OF FULL EXCLUSION FROM GROSS INCOME OF DEATH GRATUITY PAYMENT. Amendment made to exclude adjustments to death gratuity payments from being included in gross income. Effective for deaths occurring after September 10, 2001. SEC. 4. EXCLUSION FOR AMOUNTS RECEIVED UNDER DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE HOMEOWNERS ASSISTANCE PROGRAM. Section 132 is amended to include a new subsection (n) for qualified military base realignment and closure fringe benefits under the Demonstration Cities and Metropolitan Development Act of 1966. The amendments made by this section (42 U.S.C. 3374) limit payments related to property and apply to payments made after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. EXPANSION OF COMBAT ZONE FILING RULES TO CONTINGENCY OPERATIONS. The text expands the time for performing certain acts postponed due to service in a combat zone to include deployment outside the US for contingency operations designated by the Secretary of Defense. Amendments include specifying the period of the contingency operation and adding "or operation" after references to a specific area. The amendments expand the time for performing acts postponed due to service in a combat zone to include deployment for contingency operations designated by the Secretary of Defense. Amendments include specifying the period of the contingency operation and adding "or operation" after references to a specific area. Effective date applies to acts not expired before enactment of the Act. SEC. 6. Modification of membership requirement for exemption from tax for certain veterans' organizations. Amends section 501(c)(19) to include ancestors and lineal descendants. Effective for taxable years after enactment. SEC. 7. Clarification of treatment of certain dependent care assistance programs. The text chunk discusses amendments to the definition of qualified military benefits, including the inclusion of dependent care assistance programs for certain individuals. Conforming amendments are made to various sections to reflect this change. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002. SEC. 8 clarifies the exception from additional tax on certain distributions from qualified tuition programs for attendance at military academies. SEC. 8 clarifies exceptions from additional tax for distributions made for attendance at military academies like the United States Military Academy, Naval Academy, Air Force Academy, Coast Guard Academy, or Merchant Marine Academy, as long as the payment does not exceed the costs of advanced education. The amendment made by this section, defined by section 2005(e)(3) of title 10, United States Code, will take effect for taxable years starting after December 31, 2002. SEC. 9. ABOVE-THE-LINE DEDUCTION FOR OVERNIGHT TRAVEL EXPENSES OF NATIONAL GUARD AND RESERVE MEMBERS. The new provision allows members of the Reserve Component of the Armed Forces to deduct expenses related to their service away from home. This deduction is available regardless of whether the taxpayer chooses to itemize deductions. The new provision allows members of the Reserve Component of the Armed Forces to deduct expenses related to their service away from home, up to $1,500, regardless of whether the taxpayer chooses to itemize deductions. The amendments made by this section apply to expenses incurred by members of the Reserve Component of the Armed Forces for services more than 100 miles away from home, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002. Tax relief and assistance for families of astronauts who lose their lives on a space mission. Tax relief is provided for astronauts who die on a space mission, with amendments made to income tax laws. This includes applying provisions to astronauts' deaths and making conforming and clerical amendments. Amendments are made to income tax laws to provide relief for astronauts who die on a space mission. The amendments include applying provisions to astronauts' deaths and making clerical changes. Effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2002. Amendments to income tax laws provide relief for astronauts who die on a space mission. Amendments to income tax laws provide relief for astronauts who die on a space mission, with changes applying to estates of decedents after December 31, 2002. SEC. 11. PROTECTION OF SOCIAL SECURITY. Amounts transferred to Social Security trust funds under title II of the Social Security Act will be determined as if this Act had not been enacted.
